lead_paragraph: Thanks so much to all who contributed to our lively - if somewhat technologically challenged - discussion about the scientists who made bird flu take wing. Responses reflected an unusually wide array of ideas, from the conviction that nothing in the world could justify experiments like those in question to the equally impassioned conviction that nothing should get in their way. Similarly, some argued that the data these experiments produced are of only marginal usefulness, while others felt they would prove as invaluable as Galileo's discovery. But what, as Andrew S asked, is the most appropriate ethical framework for sorting through these claims? For those who might have more to say, we'll keep the comments open for a while longer. Readers, have at it!
